Tammie Haven Knick
January 24, 2019 at 10:37 AM ·

Yesterday we introduced our students to the book our whole school will be reading in small groups called “Night” by Elie Wiesel. We started off the day by doing a simulation for what it was like for the people living in Germany during the time of Hitler’s reign. We handed out different colored blocks the students had to hang around their neck and then we had students go in silence, single file, through the tunnels under the MinnWest Technology Campus and came out through the depot building and back to school where they were sorted to either the left or the right. The discussion that ensued after the simulation was amazing!! I can’t wait to start reading the book together with students on Friday.

post_text: This spoke to me today, especially since I took 11 of our students from DREAM Technical Academy to a Youth Leadership Academy in Willmar today. Students in our school know there is an unschooling process that takes place when they come from a traditional public school setting to our charter school setting. Students leave traditional school for many reasons to come to DREAM. Some are bored, some have been bullied, some see themselves as outcasts, some have been beat up by traditional school methods, some have failed miserable and have felt hopeless. For whatever reason, they leave and they come to DREAM and go through the unschooling process to find out that there is a place where learning is fun, where inclusiveness is the norm, where they find their tribe, where they no longer hate going to school, where they are no longer failures but thrivers, where they finally see hope. Our students are leaders and by coming to DREAM they took a leap of faith, they chose to not go along with the crowd but to venture out of the box into the unknown. And that is a beautiful thing! <3

post_text: Today Missy and I, met with all the new students and staff at DREAM Technical Academy this year to talk about ACEs - Adverse Childhood Experiences. We did this presentation last year with all our students and staff. You see, mental health matters to us and we want our students and staff to be informed on how adverse experiences in childhood can affect their brain, their learning, their emotions and so much more. We asked the students and staff to be vulnerable, to let down their armor, to bravely listen as we talked about some tough stuff and then we asked them to do the ACE survey. We intentionally have created a safe space for these conversations to happen. A space where hearts are opened and baggage is left at the front door. #weseeyoustudents

Does your artwork bypass the ordinary and challenge the predictable? We’re asking artists to consider what’s possible and to celebrate the marvelous and unexpected.

The VSA Emerging Young Artists Program, a Jean Kennedy Smith Arts and Disability Program, recognizes and showcases the work of emerging young artists with disabilities, ages 16-25, who are residing in the United States.

Fifteen winning artists share a total of $60,000 in awards. Grand Prize is $20,000, First Prize is $10,000, Second Prize is $6,000, and the remaining Awards of Excellence are $2,000 each. Winning artwork will be exhibited in a year-long, nationally touring exhibition, and artists will attend an all-expenses-paid professional development workshop in Washington, DC.

post_text: We are happy to announce that DREAM Technical Academy has been awarded a grant from PACT For Families Children's Collaborative in Willmar to do a project we are calling “Mental Health Matters.” The Mental Health Matters project is designed to equip DREAM students with the tools necessary to better manage stress, anxiety, and depression as well as skills needed to build resilience. Planned activities for this project include all-school programming as well as small-group work. Activities will focus on providing our students with the necessary education to make informed decisions about their physical and mental health. Stay tuned for more information as this project unfolds. #mentalhealthmatters
